questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with generalized weakness and lightheadedness for 2 weeks. Blood investigations were notable for decreased hemoglobin, increased indirect bilirubin, and increased LDH. Her peripheral smear showed RBC fragments. Which vitamin deficiency is associated with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic anemia. It is associated with a deficiency of vitamin E.

The most important function of vitamin E is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. Vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation by free radicals, thereby stabilizing cell membranes. Hence, its deficiency can result in erythrocyte membranes being abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia.

Note: Vitamin K deficiency does not cause hemolysis. It causes manifestations of impaired coagulation, such as easy bruisability, mucosal bleeding, etc. However, vitamin K toxicity can cause hemolysis.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficiency leading to this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial (perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A: Niacin deficiency leads to Pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is seen in sun-exposed areas and presents as hyperpigmentation around the neck known as Casal's necklace. An image of Casal's necklace is shown below.

Option C: Riboflavin deficiency manifests as glossitis, cheilitis, magenta-colored tongue, angular stomatitis, and circumcorneal vascularization, as shown below.

Option D: Selenium deficiency is implicated in keshan disease (Endemic cardiomyopathy) and kashin-Beck disease (Chronic, endemic osteoarthropathy).

questions.text: Which among the following helps in the maturation of collagen?
questions.solution:
Ascorbic acid/Vitamin C helps in the maturation of collagen. 

Collagen is synthesized intracellularly in fibroblasts. Each polypeptide chain of collagen has about 1000 amino acid residues composed of Glycine-X-Y repeats, where X and Y are proline and hydroxyproline predominantly.

Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues takes place intracellularly as a part of post-translational modification with the help of prolyl hydroxylase and lysyl hydroxylase. These enzymes require iron in a reduced state in its active site. Vitamin C/ascorbic acid keeps iron in a reduced state in these enzymes and thus helps in the maturation of collagen. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to scurvy which is characterized by bleeding tendencies, anemia, and skeletal abnormalities due to defective collagen in the connective tissue.

Steps of post-translational modification of collagen includes

  • Hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues
  • Glycosylation of hydroxylysine residues
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain disulfide bonds
  • Triple helix formation
  • Cleavage of 25–35 kDa portions at both carboxy and amino terminal end
  • Quartered staggered arrangement
  • Oxidative deamination of lysine and hydroxylysine residues
  • Formation of intrachain and interchain crosslinks

Other options:

Option B: Lysyl oxidase is a copper-containing enzyme that helps in covalent crosslinking collagen fibers. Deficiency of copper results in defective function of lysyl oxidase, and reduced cross-linkage of collagen leading to a condition called Menke's disease. Zinc has no role in collagen maturation.

questions.text: An underweight adolescent girl is found to have the following finding on her ocular examination. What is the WHO grade for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency. According to the WHO grading of xerophthalmia, Bitot spots are classified as 1B.

Bitos spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals a child with sparse and kinky hair. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia. These features strongly suggest a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

This results from a deficiency of its co-factor i.e copper due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
  • ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Other options:

Branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase(BCKAD) enzyme defect causes Maple syrup urine disease (Option A)

Valine transaminase enzyme defect causes Hypervalinemia (Option B)

A defect in Cystathionine synthase causes Homocystinuria type I (Option D)

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A child presents with lesions as shown in the image below. He also complained of decreased vision at night. Which of the following dose of vitamin A prophylaxis given to children under the vitamin A distribution scheme in India could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given yearly between the ages 1-6 years
1,00,000 IU  given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years
2,00,000 IU given 6-monthly between the ages 1-6 years

questions.solution:
The image above showing phrynoderma along with the history of decreased vision at the night suggests a likely diagnosis of vitamin A deficiency. Under the vitamin-A distribution scheme in India, 200,000 IU of vitamin A are given orally at 6-monthly intervals between the ages of 1 to 6 years.

Vitamin A deficiency is a major preventable cause of blindness in children. It can lead to mucocutaneous disease and result in various ocular complications, including blindness. The earliest sign of vitamin A deficiency is defective dark adaptation and night blindness (nyctalopia). Xerosis and scaling are commonly present in cutaneous findings. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by the presence of keratotic follicular papules over anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms is also seen.

Treatment is done by administering 50,000–2,00,000 IU of daily vitamin A supplementation until clinical signs and symptoms resolve and serum retinol levels normalize. 

The image below shows a Bitot's spot(due to Vitamin A deficiency) seen as a foamy appearance on the surface of the conjunctiva.

questions.text:
The required increase in caloric intake of a lactating mother in the first 6 months is __

PHC: Primary health care
questions.solution:
During the first six months of lactation, an increase of 600 Kcal/day is recommended, and from 7-12 months of lactation, an addition of 520 Kcal/day is recommended.

Pregnancy requires an additional 80,000 kcal during the last 20 weeks. This intake is not equally divided during pregnancy. It is divided as 0, ~340, and 350 kcal/day in the first, second, and third trimester, respectively. 

Pregnancy is a period where a mother will require additional nutritional requirements to support the healthy growth and development of the fetus. According to the recommended dietary allowances by the Indian council of medical research (ICMR):

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue. She had pallor on physical examination. Lab values are given below. Serum methyl malonyl CoA levels are normal. Which of the following should be administered as a therapy for this patient?

Hemoglobin - 9.8 g/dL

Platelets - 1,80,000/mm3

Leukocyte count - 7800/mm3

MCV - 106 fl
questions.solution:
This patient has megaloblastic anemia (high MCV). This could be due to various causes, commonly Vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency. The presence of normal methylmalonyl Co-A favors folic acid deficiency. Thus folic acid has to be given as supplements.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine and is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (Homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, in vitamin B12 deficiency methyl-tetrahydrofolate accumulates leading to functional folate deficiency known as the folate trap.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

Causes of megaloblastic anaemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: Nutritional, Malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/ partial gastrectomy.
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism.
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate.
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukaemia, myelodysplasia.
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine).
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came to OPD with a tingling sensation in her legs and hands. The oral examination shows the following features. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing the riboflavin deficiency that this patient has. The image shows cheilosis and angular stomatitis which point towards riboflavin deficiency. The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase.

Deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  • Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin.

  • Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

questions.text: An undernourished child is brought for consultation. You prescribe a mineral supplement that is absorbed by the mechanism shown in the image below. Identify the supplement.
questions.solution:
The given image shows iron absorption and transport from a duodenal enterocyte into the blood, hence the mineral supplement prescribed can be identified as an iron supplement.

The following image shows in detail, the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte.

Dietary iron is available in two forms - heme and non-heme iron. Initially, the ferric non-heme iron is reduced to ferrous iron by duodenal cytochrome B (ferric reductase) or by vitamin C. The reduced ferrous iron is then transferred into the enterocyte by DMT 1 (divalent metal transporter). 

Heme iron moves into the cytoplasm with the help of transporters. Here, it is metabolized to release ferrous iron, which then follows the same pathway as non-heme iron.

Once inside the enterocyte, it can either get stored as ferritin or transferred across the basolateral membrane by ferroportin. In the plasma, iron is transported in the Fe3+ form bound to transferrin, which is a transport protein. Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that oxidizes Fe2+ to Fe3+ before it is transported.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby iron absorption too. Thus, iron is trapped in the intestinal cells which is eventually sloughed off. Hepcidin also inhibits the release of iron from macrophages by binding to ferroportin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate

questions.text: Magnesium does not have a role in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Magnesium has no role in copper metabolism.

Magnesium is a major intracellular cation required for the function of various enzymes such as hexokinase, phosphofructokinase, alkaline phosphatase, enolase, etc.

The role of magnesium can be seen in the following processes:

  • Calcium homeostasis: One-half of the total body magnesium is located in bone. Magnesium is important for PTH secretion which controls serum Ca2+ level.
  • Neuromuscular function: Hypomagnesemia may cause generalized alterations in neuromuscular function including tetany, tremor, seizures. Hypermagnesemia is known to cause symptoms of neuromuscular blockade such as hypoactive tendon reflexes, GI hypomotility, paralysis, etc
  • Maintenance of cardiac rhythm: Hypomagnesemia can lead to supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias. Hypermagnesemia can cause bradycardia, heart block, and asystole.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below:
questions.solution:
The image provided is characteristic of Casal's necklace, seen in pellagra, and indicates a deficiency of Tryptophan.

Pellagra can occur due to:

  • Vitamin B3 (niacin)
    • Niacin is derived from tryptophan and needs B2 and B6 for its synthesis.
  • Hartnup's disease (tryptophan malabsorption)
  • Malignant carcinoid syndrome (↑ tryptophan metabolism)
  • Isoniazid (↓ vitamin B6)

In Hartnup's disease, defective membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes leads to malabsorption of tryptophan. This causes a deficiency of tryptophan.

As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced and this manifests as pellagra with dermatitis, diarrhea and dementia (3D's) and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called the Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

questions.text: Methyltetrahydrofolic acid gets accumulated in deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolic acid is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, in vitamin B12 deficiency methyl-tetrahydrofolate accumulates leading to functional folate deficiency known as the folate trap.

 

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

Note: Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well. This in turn increases the risk of atherosclerosis, hypertension, and thrombosis.

questions.text: A 45-year old man who was a chronic alcoholic presented with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the treatment protocol?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of wernicke's encephalopathy and treatment is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose containing IV fluids.

The patient's symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and diplopia strongly suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, a neurological disorder commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol abuse. This condition arises due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which impairs the function of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine is an essential cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase, a key component of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex that converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This conversion is critical for linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle, thereby facilitating energy production in the body.

Without sufficient thiamine, the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase is severely impaired, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood, causing lactic acidosis. This biochemical disturbance contributes to the neurological symptoms observed. Immediate administration of thiamine is crucial in treating Wernicke's encephalopathy. If left untreated, the condition can progress to Korsakoff syndrome, a chronic and debilitating memory disorder. Thus, recognizing the signs and symptoms early and providing thiamine supplementation can lead to rapid improvement and prevent long-term complications.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

    1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

  • Global confusion
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Horizontal nystagmus 

    2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

  • Memory loss
  • Confabulation

    3. Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

questions.text: A 20-year-old bodybuilder presented with fatigue on moderate exercise. He had recently started eating raw eggs for protein. Which of the following enzymes is likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The patient developed pyruvate carboxylase enzyme deficiency.

Individuals who eat an excess of uncooked egg-white, develop biotin deficiency and as a result deficiency of the carboxylase enzymes. This is because a protein called, avidin present in the egg-white binds to biotin in the diet, and makes biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption.

Biotin deficiency can cause:

  • Dermatitis
  • Mental status changes (depression, hallucinations)
  • Paraesthesia
  • Alopecia

Biotin serves as a co-enzyme for the synthesis of several carboxylase enzymes such as:

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of imbalance, numbness of the foot, and muscle weakness. On history taking, he revealed that he has been taking multivitamin tablets more than the prescribed dose for 1 year. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the associated symptoms seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette points towards the diagnosis of vitamin B6 toxicity due to excess intake of vitamin B6 supplements.

The active form of vitamin B6/pyridoxine is pyridoxal phosphate(PLP). PLP acts as a coenzyme for many reactions such as transaminations, decarboxylations, metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids, heme synthesis, niacin synthesis, and glycogenolysis.

Drugs that decrease pyridoxine levels include isoniazid, cycloserine,oral contraceptives, and alcohol. Deficiency manifestations of vitamin B6 include convulsions, peripheral neuritis, pellagra due to decreased niacin synthesis, and hypochromic microcytic anemia due to inhibition of heme synthesis. Vitamin B6 levels can be measured by erythrocyte transaminase assay.

Excessive intake of food-based sources of pyridoxine doesn’t cause toxicity, the only source of pyridoxine toxicity is from the intake of supratherapeutic dosing of supplements more than 100-200mg/day or iatrogenic. Pyridoxine toxicity manifests as neurological symptoms including numbness, tingling sensation, muscle weakness, and difficulty in ambulation in severe cases.

Other options:

Option A: Intake of vitamin D of more than 10,000 units per day can cause toxicity and it manifests as weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension, weight loss, and metastatic calcification(calcinosis).

Option C: 

Clinical features of Vitamin C toxicity:

  • Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, nausea
  • Increased prevalence of kidney stones (oxalate)
  • Iron overload (in patients on supplement iron)
  • Hemolysis (G6PD deficiency)

Option D: Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.

questions.text: A mother complains that her child is reluctant when it comes to taking feeds appropriately. Her 15-month-old boy has a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a length-for-age ≤ –2 SD below the median is having moderate stunting.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight for height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. It is also called as wasting as a result of a recent food deficit or an acute illness such as diarrhea.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight for age, or underweight indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is an age-independent parameter used for screening wasting in children. Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age) is given in the pearl below.

questions.text: Lathyrism is caused by which of the following toxic compounds?
questions.solution:
BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) is the toxic compound causing Lathyrism.

It is due to the consumption of Khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus. Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals.

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs.

The water soluble property of the toxin is used in removing from the pulses by soaking it in hot water and rejecting the soaked water. Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman from China has an echocardiography report showing dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following conditions could account for her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is characteristic, and may also result in cardiomegaly, congestive cardiac failure and fulminant cardiogenic shock. Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine.

There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as, Glutathione peroxidase, De-iodinase, Thioredoxin reductase. Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Clinical correlates:

  • Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low.

  • Selenium toxicity (Kashinbeck Disease): Chronic ingestion of high amounts of selenium leads to selenosis (Kashinbeck disease). It is characterized by hair and nail brittleness, garlic breath odor, myopathy, irritability, and other abnormalities of the nervous system.

Other options :

Option a : Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency leads to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which are characterized by symptoms such as muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular issues, and confusion. While cognitive dysfunction can result from thiamine deficiency, rash and loose stools do not fit with thiamine deficiency. Therefore, thiamine would not address the full spectrum of this patient’s symptoms.

Option c : Zinc deficiency causes acrodermatitis enteropathica. It presents after weaning with diarrhea, alopecia, and a cutaneous eruption in the periorificial and acral areas. Children often have symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with crusted edges. It is associated with nutritional alopecia like marasmus and kwashiorkor but flag sign is not seen.

Option d : Copper deficiency leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia and mental retardation.

questions.text: An 8 month-old baby is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss and failure to thrive. On clinical examination, there is inflammation of the skin around the mouth and the perianal region. The mineral deficiency responsible for this disease is?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and clinical findings, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to the deficiency of zinc.

It is an autosomal recessive disease due to a defect in zinc absorbing transmembrane protein.

Symptoms:

  • Growth retardation
  • Diarrhea
  • Alopecia
  • Rash involving the extremities, face, and perineum(rash is characterized by vesicular and pustular crusting with scaling and erythema)
  • Gonadal atrophy
  • Muscle wasting
  • Impaired wound healing

questions.text: A patient has profuse bleeding after the removal of an IV cannula. He underwent a small bowel resection and was given broad-spectrum antibiotics during his hospital stay. His lab investigations show an elevated prothrombin time (PT). The deficiency of which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of vitamin K is responsible for this condition.

Vitamin K deficiency in adults may be seen in patients with chronic small-intestinal diseases like celiac disease, Crohn’s disease, obstructed biliary tracts, and after small-bowel resection. Additionally, broad-spectrum antibiotics can precipitate Vitamin K deficiency by reducing the number of gut bacteria, which synthesize menaquinones.

It is a fat-soluble vitamin that has two natural forms: Vitamin K1, also known as phylloquinone, from vegetable sources, and vitamin K2, or menaquinones, which are synthesized by bacterial flora and found in hepatic tissue.

Vitamin K is required for the posttranslational carboxylation of glutamic acid, which is necessary for calcium binding to γ-carboxylated proteins such as

  • prothrombin (factor II)
  • factors VII, IX, and X
  • protein C, protein S

Patients with vitamin K deficiency usually present with a history of bleeding either at venipuncture sites or minor trauma.

It is diagnosed on the basis of an elevated prothrombin time or reduced clotting factors. It is treated with supplementation by oral or IV route.

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin or Vitamin B2 deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Option B: Vitamin E deficiency manifests as peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy. Usually seen with fat malabsorption or genetic abnormalities of vitamin E metabolism.

Option C: Niacin deficiency manifests as pellagra, which includes symptoms of diarrhea, a pigmented rash over sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, memory loss, and altered sensorium. Alcoholism, vitamin B6 deficiency, riboflavin, and tryptophan deficiencies predispose to this condition.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes Keshan's disease?
questions.solution:
Keshan disease is due to a deficiency of selenium.

Selenium is an important trace element which is a part of the 21st amino acid Selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant which complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, meat, and some cereals.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Dilated cardiomyopathy is the characteristic feature, but it may also result in congestive cardiac failure, cardiomegaly, and fulminant cardiogenic shock. It is associated with tumorigenesis (increased risk of progression to metaplasia) and atherosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Thiamine deficiency leads to Beri-beri and Wernicke–Korsakoff’s syndrome.

Option C: Zinc deficiency causes acrodermatitis enteropathica. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhoea, recurrent infections, alopecia, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, irritability, and night blindness. Skin changes include vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities, perianal and perioral regions. Chronic zinc deficiency can cause stunted growth, decreased taste sensation(hypogeusia), impaired immune function and hypogonadism, and hypopigmented hair.

Option D: Copper deficiency can present as anemia, cardiovascular defects including aneurysms, hypopigmentation, and neurological symptoms such as ataxia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common deficiency observed after gastric bypass/bariatric surgery?
questions.solution: Iron deficiency is the most common deficiency observed following gastric bypass or bariatric surgery. Iron is absorbed in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, bypass procedures lead to or exacerbate an existing deficiency by impairing absorption. It is more common in the Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS) procedures than in sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
